Hopkins tandem to testify in Washington
Sheldon Himelfarb, chairman
of the Student Council's
Financial Aid Committee, will
testify tomorrow at a public
hearing of the HEW's Office of
Education task force and advise
that proposed regulations for
student aid be liberalized.
Hopkins will also be
represented at the Washington,
D.C. hearing by Judy Munaker,
assistant- director of Financial
Aid, who will speak on behalf of
the Maryland, Delaware, and
Washington, D.C. Association of
Financial Aid Administrators.
Both Himelfarb and Munaker
will recommend that the task
force reconsider two of its major
Policy suggestions:
—that the average workload
for a Work-Study student should
not exceed 20 hours per week
—and that 80 percent of a
student's summer earning should
be considered as resources for
college-related expenses.
They also plan to challenge
HEW's existing policy that all of
a student's earnings outside of
federal assistance programs must
be subtracted from his Financial
Aid package.
Munaker and Himelfarb said
yesterday that they feel the
package of proposed regulations
represents impediment to the
effectiveness of the Work-Study
program and the National Direct
Student Loan program.
"We're asking them not to
regulate things like a student's
work capacity on Work-Study,"

explained Munaker. "These
decisions should be made by the
individual student and his
Financial Aid advisors."
Said Himelfarb of the
regulations, "They take away a
lot of the incentive for earning,
especially for Work-Study
students."
He and Munaker both consider
the provision for summer earning
a potentially harmful policy.
"That suggestion leaves only 20
percent of a student's income for
living expenses," commented
Himelfarb.
"There's no way to exist on a
figure like that," he added.
The HEW task force will seek
to put the policy suggestions into
law by amending the Higher
Education Act, a change which
HEW can make on its own,

Glen Thomas

task force "has received a lot of
written comments and is
expecting a huge turnout."
He is hopeful that the
testimony will occasion some
revision in the proposed
regulations. "We want to make a
convincing case for student
concerns," stated Himelfarb.
"We're going to point out that
these regulations go against the
student interest."

Brown Infirmary to be examined
The Student Council is
investigating the health services
provided by the Brown Memorial
Infirmary following several
complaints from dorm residents.
According to Eric Schwartz,
Freshman class representative,
the Infirmary's emergency
system—whereby a doctor or
nurse is on call 24 hours a
day—has broken down several
times this semester.
Schwartz related that a
student recently was forced to
wait 20 minutes for an
ambulance to be called after
falling off of a second floor
landing, even though the
Infirmary had been contacted. In
another incident, the doctor on
call was unavailable when a
student injured her finger in a
door. She was taken to an area
hospital.
Schwartz said that in the latter
case, the doctor's answering
service never informed him of the
emergency call. He pointed out
that .no alternative medical

personnel were named by the
University operator, who
provided the on-call doctor's
number.
Schwartz, who is involved in
distributing information to
dormitory residents concerning
available emergency services,
proposes two steps to improve
health services for dormitory
residents.
First, he suggests a list be
made of all doctors and nurses
associated with the health
program and given to all dorm
residents, in case the primary
physician or nurse on call should
be unavailable during an
emergency. Presently, only
housemasters have copies of this
list. Schwartz claimed that
sometimes it is impossible to
contact a housemaster.
While he acknowledged that
having a doctor of nurse at
Brown Memorial Infirmary
around the clock—a system in
effect until three years
ago—might be unduly costly, he

advocates a policy whereby a
nurse or doctor would be within
15 minutes of the campus at all
times.
Schwartz stated that he is
working with Dean of Students
Jakie Hall to persuade the
University Health Service to
make these changes. He added
that to this point he has found
Joan Ferrara, head nurse at the
Brown Memorial Infirmary, and
the rest of the health service
"uncooperative."
Ferrara refused comment
when contacted last night.
Schwartz added that the
Student Council is also
investigating medical services for
off-campus students.
The Student Council Health
Services Committee is currently
examining the overall picture for
health services at Homewood.
Working in conjunction with
Ferrara, the panel will draw up a
written evaluation with
suggestions about the emergency
services.
